intro: Cassebeeria affinis, commonly known as the red-veined nettle, is a flowering plant native to tropical regions of Africa. It belongs to the family Urticaceae, which includes many species known for their stinging hairs. The plant typically grows as an upright herb with serrated, lance-shaped leaves that have distinctive red veins. Its small, greenish-white flowers are clustered in dense inflorescences, and it is often found in moist, shaded environments. Cassebeeria affinis is valued for its ornamental appeal and has been used in traditional medicine in some cultures.
